ARTICLE /. This Association shall be
called the Society for the encouragement Of
Free Labor: It's object shall be to encour-
age the cultivation Of such articles BY Free
men as arc now produced by the labor of
slaves; and to collect and disseminate intor-
nation calculated to promote the object Of
this Association.


ARr.2. The Officers Of this society shall
be elected annually AZ the first stated meet
ing of each year. They shall be President,
two vice Presidents, a Secretary, Treasurer
and Acting Committee, to be composed Of
six members.


ARTS. The President shall act as Chair
man at tho meetings of the .Associa-
ton. In case Of his absence one Of the vice
Presidents, or some other member shall rep.
resent him as the meeting may direct and
in all questions when the votes of the other
members shall be equal, the Chairman shall
have a casting vote.


| ART. 4. The Secretary shall keep fair
minutes ot the Soclcty's proceedings; coun-
tersign all orders on the Treasurer, and no.
tify members OF the time and place OF meet


ug,


ARTS. The Treasurer shall hold the
funds of the Association, and pay all orders
for money in his hands, drawn on him by
direction Of the Society, signed by the Pres
ident or one OF the vice Presidents, and coun-
tersigned by the Secretary.


ART. 6. The Acting Committee shall
CORES spond with individuals or societies in
our own or foreign countries, who may be
able to furnish information calculated to pro-
mote the objects OF this society, and shall
have particularly in view the encouragement
Of Free Labor in the slave districts Of the


United States, by promoting the consump.
tion of its products as widely AS practicable


and by such other means as may appear tc


be adapted to tha, important end


ART. 7. The meetings Of this socict,
shall be held quarterly, on the second Mon
day in January, April, July and October


and at any intermediate tunes, either by ad


ournment, Of by call of the President ant
Secretary, CT any five members Of the asso


cat on.


ART, 8. Any person may become mcm


Der Of this Society by signing the constitu


ton and paying to the Treasurer the sum 0
, fifty cents


A ART. Q, Six members shall constitute
, quorum for the transaction OF business. AM
: all questions, except such as relate to alter
S atcns OF the constitution, shall be decide
: by the majority of members present.
= ART. 10. All monies except the admis


sion fees, necessary for the use Of the socie


ty, shall be raised among the members b
: voluntary contribution.


e ART. IL. The members Of this associatio
: shall give preference to particles the produc
. of Free Labor, where such can be procure
:, without pecuniary sacrifice.
ART. 10. No alterations shall DC mad
= in this constitution, except the propositiu
" to alter shall have been made at precedir
- meeting, and shall be agreed to by thre,
oi fourths of the members present.
CONSTITUTION

The adviccs from Carthagcna, TO the 10th hlt.
by the Bunker Hill. states, says the New-York
Mercantile, that Bolivar arrived at Bogota on the
18th of November, and proceeded for Venczue-
la OIL the 25th, From thence he was expected
TO arrive at Carthagena about the 10th to the 15th
Of January. The seat of Government was to be
established for the present at the latter place, or
at Turbaco, - miles distant. The private let
tiers, state, that on arriving at Bogota, Bolivar
took decisive measures to restore order--that he
invested himself with the authority given him by
the Constitution in cases of insnrrecton; that he
had despatched Santander to Peru, abolished
the officers of Secretary of Foreign Affairs and
of the Navy--ordercd the ARMY to be reduced 70
5000 men, and increased the pay of the officers
in tine navy 100 per cent. The intcntlant at Car
thagena, was to be removed. 1t is also stated
that a Convention of the people was to be called.
The letters enclose the following Proclamation


PROCLAMATION OF BOLIVAR.


Colombians Five years since left this capito
to march at the head of the Liberating army tron
the shore of the Cauca to the silvery heights Of
Potosi. million of Colombians, two sister Re
publcs, have obtained independence under the

sether With threats of rctaiiaton ut the ILL
human treatment it was supposed the gener-
al had received from the encmy, viz that
he had been bayonctted after having surrcn-
dered and asked for quarters: when the
magnanimous Mercer observcd--Ihe tale
which you have heard, George, is untrue
My death is owing to myself. was on foot,
endeavoring to rally my men, who had gwen
way before the superior discipline OF the en-
emy. when was brought to the ground by
blow from a musket. At the same moment
the enemy discovered my rank, exulted in
their having taken he rebel general, as
they termed me, and bid me ask Tor quar-
ters. | felt that deserved not so opprobrl-
Gus an epithet, and determined to die as had
lived, an honored soldier in a just and right
eous cause; and without begging my lite or
making reply, lunged with my sword at
the nearest man. They then bayonetted and
left me.


While the surgeons were dressing his
wounds. of which he had received thirteen,
the general, who was himself regularly
bred and eminent surgeon, remanded, "Nef-
cr mind those; they are mere scratches
Look under my arm, and there you viii Ind
fellow that will soon do my business"


We shall here rcpubish an anecdote
(Which we have given in another work. ct
the noble and dsinterested devotion OF the
amentcd Mercer, to that "just and righteous
cause" which he sealed with his blood on
the field Of Princeton.


When the southern troops we're first or
ganizing for the Army Of independence, nu-
merous applications for commissions were
made 10 the House OF Burgcsses of Virginia.
They were mostly from young men of for
tune and family interest, and seldom asked
for less than field officers rank. Mercer,
a veteran associate OF Washington in the
war of SO, and deservedly high in his conf
dcncc aud esteem, pressed not in the crowd,
urged no solicitations, sought no patronage,
but wrote on scrap OF paper and handed 1t
to the speaker, with the following words
"IIugh Mercer will serve his country in any
rank to which he may be appointed" He
received regiment forthwith.


He lies buried in Philadelphia, where a
plain slab, with the initials II NJ. denotes
the last earthly dwelling Of the patriot
brave.

Our work will contain memoirs of many
of the distinguished worthless, who shared
with their chief the perils and glorles of the
tays of trial. Their virtues and heroic ac-
tions can no where be better commemorated
than in eRecollections" of him who was at
once their revered commander, father, and
friend.


The historical registers of the war of the
revolution are all in error, in their narratives
of the death of Gen. Mercer. We offer the
homage of our veneration for his martyred
memory, in giving to his country and the
world authentic details of the heroism and
devotion, which attended his fall.-Our au-
thority is derived from the late Major Geo.
Lewis, the nephew, of the commander-in-
chief. captain Of his guard, and who was sent
in with Gag to afford to the wounded gen
eral every possible comfort and assistance,
and in whose arms the lamented hero ex-
pired.


Lewis expressed the extreme indignation
which prevailed in the American army, to-

The Sierra Leone Gazette of the 9th s,p,sn.
lions most atrocious act Of barbarity, on the part
Of a French slave Captain, named Gibson This
fellow had carried off from the Gallinas, about
six weeks before, 250 slaves, whom he INTENDED
to introduce surreptitiously into Guadaloupe
He succeeded in landing the whole, except 6i,
when having observed French Government
cutter coming towards his vessel, he threw sixty.
five miserable beings overheard, in order to AVOID
discovery of the traffic he had been carving
on! The Governor of Gaudaloupe, it is added
gave orders to seize the murderer, when the crime
he had perpetrated was discovered by the deai
bodies that were drfted ashore, but he had soil
ed before the order could be executed.

In the Senate on Tuesday, 9th inst. the "Bil
TO provide for the location Of the two townships
of land reserved for seminary of learning in the
Territory of Florida, and to complete the loca-
ton Of the grant to the Deaf and Dumb Asylum
of Kentucky" after some discussion, was order
ed to a third reading. The "Bill to graduate the
price Of public land, and to cedc the refuse to
the States in which they lie," was considered,
and strongly opposed, in an able speech, by Mr..
Barton The bill, with an amendment, propos-
ed by Mr.. Hendricks, was postponed TO the Goth
inst.


In the House Of Representatives the day
was entirely occupied in the discussion of the
resolutions laid on the table the preceding day,
by Mr.. Blair, Of Tennessee, and Mr. Wiclifie Of
Kentucky. The two former were agreed to,
with amendments; and the discussion OF the lat.
ter was suspended by call for the orders of the
day. The further consideration of the Resolu-
tionary Officers and Soldiers bill was postponed
until tomorrow.


The select committe appointed on the subject
of the letter Of the Vice President on motion of
Mr.. Floyd, obtained leave to sit during the sit
ting ofthe House.


The system Of Cavalry Tractics prepared by
the Board of Officers which of Gen Scott was
President, was received from the War Depart
ment, and ordered 10 be printed.


In the Senate. the bill authorizing the Presid
ent ofthe United States to cause the reserved
lead mines of Missouri to be exposed to sale. was
considered, and after some discussion, was laid
on the table. The bill for opening military roads
in the Territory of Michigan. was then taken up,
and after an animated debate, was laid on the
table.


In the House Of Representatives, Mr.. Mercer
laid resolution on the table calling for nforma-
ton relative to the Custom House receipts from
1885, TO the present time. A Bill was reported
from the Committee on Manufactures, relative to
duties on imports; and bill from the Military
Committee, to increase the Corps OF Engineers.
The resolution offered by Mr.. wicklhee, and
discussed on the preceding day, was adopted
with modification The House then went into
Committee on the bill providing for the rclin.
9uishment of certain claims to lands sold by the
United States in the State of Ohio, but rose with
aut taking vote upon it, and obtained leave tc
sit again. message from the President Wa
received, communicating an interesting repor
from the Secretary of the Navy, relative TO ID!
Docks; and communication from the War De
partment, containing the names OF the officers o
the Revolutionary Army, as far as they could b'
furnished.


In the Senate, on Thursday, bill was report
cd for reducing the duties on certain importc'
articles. A bill was reported for increasing tn
sa...rv Of the Post Master General to G,O0O do
lars. Mr. nickerson, from the Select Commit
tee TO which was referred the bill for distributing
a portion of the national revenue among III
States, reported the same Mr. Smith, OF Nd
submitted aresolution proposing an inquiry int
the expedency ofreducing the balance ofthe tw
millions authorized TO be kept in the Treasury
20 one million, and Of appropria;ing the same t
the payment OF the debt due to the Coinmlssior
era Of the Sinking Fund,


The House of Representatives was principal
occupied in the discussion OF the Reyolltlonar
Bill, but adjourned without coming to vote
slr Livingston moved the House to take up h
resolution on the subject of the Greeks, and ash
ed for the ayes and noes on the question, who
ehe House refused TO consiusr it, by vote
100 to 54


In the Senate on Friday, the bill to reduce ii
duties on imported wines, teas, gunpowder, ar
salt, was read second time. The bill to increa'
the salary of the Post Master General was aft'
come discussion, ordered to third reading. TT
bill to establish an uniform system OF Bankruptc
throughout the United States, was made the sp
cial order of the day for Monday next.


The House of Representatives was engaged
the discussion of the bill to provide for the of
GERS and soldiers of the army Of the Revolutio
The question was taken by Ayes and Noes,
motion Of Mr.. Tucker, which was negatived by
vote of 160to 80 Mr. WickhHe then moved
Introduce the words "and the heirs and repr
sentatves ofthose who have dicd,' and on Il
question the ayes and noes were ordered, hut b
fore the question was taken, the House adjour
ed.


The Senate did not sit on Saturday.


In the House of Representatives, the di
cussion OF the Bill to make provision for Il
officers and soldiers OF the army of the Re
olution was resumed; but no question W
taken. Mr.. Wickliffe made few observ
ba md fnI
BY Mr.. Test and Mr.. Clarke against t
bill, and Mr.. Sprague and Mr., Drayton,


the other side. Mr.. Wecms also obtain
the floor, and then yielded it to motion


adjournment.

The Bank of England has declared half

Gen. Outrage, who with many others OF
the Constitutional Exllcs remains in London
has declared his intention OF Immediately
leaving that country, and proceeding to Por-
Sugal, to range himself under the banners,
and to fight the battles of the Constitution.
II is said that several hundreds ofthc Span
ish and Italian refugees have also resolved
to accompany him.


Letters from Madrid state, that the Por-
tuguese insurgents were supplied with arms
from the Spanish factories, and that orders
have been given to the Supreme Council of
War to report as to the most prompt and et-
fectual manner of raising 0,o00 men.


The Courier Francois says, that the lead
ers of the Portuguese refugees have receiv.
ed from Paris the advice to seize as they ad
vance in Portugal, all property belonging to
British merchants, not only to indemnify
themselves for the expenses of the expedi-
ton but e. create forthenselves guarantee e
in case of ultrrior events. Whether advised
or not, it seems they adopted this course
when they pundcred Braganza.


The forces under the insurgent Chiei, the
Marquis Chaves, amounted to 5000, when
he entered Portugal. and it was supposed
they would soon swell to 5000.


PORTUGAL.-The following is an ex-
tract of private letter from Oporto.


"OPORTO, Dec. l, 1926.


.'NVe were all in great CONSERVATION this
morning on account of the news from the
frontiers. The Marquis de Chaves has en-
tered Braganza with 2090 men, and there
beng only 500 regular troops in the place
they fought and retired to the castle. AT
terwards general sack took place; every
house was robbed, aud the female inhabit
ants insulted; the carnage was great among
the troops. What is most to be dreaded il
the rise ofsthe sans culotte, to whom il
promised a pilIage, and they are ripe fol
it,"


The Portuguese Government, whicl
learned on the morning of the 23d, the inva
Sion OF lras-os- Montes, wrote by the Min
lister of Foreign Affairs the same evening Il
the Marquis dc Casa Flores. the Spanish
Ambassador at Lisbon, that his functions a
Ambassador were at an end, and that when
ever he wished, passports to quit Portuga
would be given to him. This fact is exact
very exact---and there is no doubt that TIL
Portuguese Government would not have a
adopted this abrupt proceeding withou
the advice of Sir w. A'Court, it is pre-
sumed that its conduct will regulate that q
Mr.. Lamb, who will doubtless terminate hi
mission at Madrid in as abrupt way as tina
Of NJ dc Casa Flores ended at Lisbon.

' "a appears To have been a very seyrrr one
for we are assured the number killed AN
wounded OH Tie two sides amounted to abou

Upon this measure of the British Gov

at is not 10 be disguised that this step in

every eye in this country will at once be
turned towards Cuba. the only possession OF
spain that can alone compensate Great Brit
ain for the expenses and evils of a war with

defence of Portugal-not OF aggression, but
of reprcsslon;--and j. that ground be ad-

quest But the temptation is great--the
facilities great. the prize invaluable On
the other hand, France and the tniteI States
/ will not, cannot. acquiesce in the island OF
Cuba passing under British dominion; and
an attempt therefore TO wrest that island
from Span, unless under the most positive
and SUBSTANTIAL pledges that its mdepen-
dcncc. under the guaranty of all the three
nations, shall be- the consequence. win lead
most certainly To universal war. II is prop
er, however, to say. that, according TO the

not anticipated that the war would involve

December to the 9Th Of February. Mr.. Peal
gave notice that the subject of the Corn
Laws will be brought before the house Of


Parliament on the twelfth Of February,


when the views of Ministers will be fully
explained.

land transmitted the following message to

ain"

"The Marquis de Bolgida, Comptroller
General had a sudden attack of apoplexy,
which ended. as it MAS thought, ia his death,
He was dressed in the habit Of Monk. as is
the common custom of our country, and de-
posted III the vault of the Church Of St,
Iuste, his parish


"However, at eleven o'clock. last night,
the Marquis awoke from his lcthargy, rails
ed himself from the coffin (for in general our
collins are not fastcned) and his fear giving
him additional strength, he made lis way to
the grating Of the vault opening to the street,
and called to the FIRST person he saw, who,
frightened IN hrs turn, ran away AS fast as
he could, calling out that ghosts were Com
ing forth from the vault of St, Juste. The
Marquis finding himself thus treated, recol-
lected the name of IA carpenter known to
him, and who lived opposite, and called on
him SO loudly, that he succeeded in waking
him. The carpenter went out, and though
not much pleased to hear himself called up
OH from place, the inhabitants of which
are generally very taciturn, by degrees, col
lected his thoughts, understood what the
Marquis wished him to do and went mme-
diately to give the Cure Of the Parish an ac-
count of what had taken place. The Mar

to his home, where lie now remains i'll in bed
and on the point Of really dying, through the
supposed death which he lately suffered.

Cast Metal Pianos.-Every day the use
Of cast iron is becoming more general
bridges are made OF it; steam boats; in Eng
land it is used for roads; and az Liverpool
churches are built of it. Here. in Paris, we
have lately got Pianos, the frame work OF
which is formed Of cast iron, These nstru-
ments have been brought to such perfection
by MN. pleyel and Co, that not only do
they rival, but 10 many particulars, surpass
the best English Instruments. The soldity

Paris, Nov. e0--On Friday night, at IL
o'clock, an individual, who was passing IN
the Rue DIES Fosscs. .MOntmartre, where he
lodged, was accostcd BY four robbers, who
demanded his purse. Upon his offering re-
sistance, thrY wrapped towel about his
head, stabbed him i'll seven places in the left
arm, threw him down, and took from him
watch, and about four thousand francs,
which were enclosed in belt. 1t seems
that two persons, passing "A moment after
wards, when he was still mpluring assist
ance fed from him, supposing his cries were
but the manGuvre OF some assassin These
persons, meeting a party of gen-d' 'armes,
sent them to the spot, where they picked up
the man and conve, ed him to the Commls-
sarv of Police, to whom he related what had
happened. He remained there fnr the night
| and patroles were sent out in all directions.
| The wounds, we understand, are likely to
be OF serious consequence. The Williams un-
fortunately escaped. Upon Change it was
said yesterday, that the man inflicted the
wounds upon himself, and pretended he had
been robbed, in order to account for the alb
sense Of considerable sum which he had


lost by gambling. The horses of u gentle
mans carriage, which was waiting near one
of the theatres, i'll the absence Of the coach
man, were Embarrassed and taken away,
and no trace as yet been found OF them. 1t
is dangerous to walk the streets at night


You will scarcely credit i, but person was


stopped and robbed OF his watch last week
on the pont des Arts, where there is a toll


keeper and guards at each cnd.--Distress
; however, seems to be the grand cause ot


these crimes. for of the numbers who have


hcen arrested, the greater part are III the
most dreadful state.

shadow Of your banners and the World OF 60
lumbus has ceased to be Spanish. Such is inc
result of our absence.


Your misfortunes have called me back to Co
lombi: come full of zeal to consecratc myself TO
the national will, which shall be my CODE be-
cause it is infallible.


The national voice obligcs me to take upon
myself the supreme command; ! abhor 1t mortal
", since by that am accused of ambition and all
attempt at monarchy What 10 they think me
so mad as to aspire to degrade MYSELF DO thcy
not know that the destiny of LlRERAIok IS
more sublime than Throne.


Colombians; return to summit to the 'hsup-

mcnts of danger to give it up were cowardlce'
not moderation: yet count on me only until inc
law or the people recover their sovereignty
Permit me then to serve you as PLAN soio,cf
and true republican, as citizen armed ~ oe-
fence ofthc beautiful trophies OF our VICTORIES
your rights. BOih' An'

full articles.headline:
CONSTITUTION

O The JtWmmgton Soc,ety far The cnc1nr.


agemcnt If Free LQbor.
full articles.article:
ARTICLE /. This Association shall be
called the Society for the encouragement Of
Free Labor: It's object shall be to encour-
age the cultivation Of such articles BY Free
men as arc now produced by the labor of
slaves; and to collect and disseminate intor-
nation calculated to promote the object Of
this Association.


ARr.2. The Officers Of this society shall
be elected annually AZ the first stated meet
ing of each year. They shall be President,
two vice Presidents, a Secretary, Treasurer
and Acting Committee, to be composed Of
six members.


ARTS. The President shall act as Chair
man at tho meetings of the .Associa-
ton. In case Of his absence one Of the vice
Presidents, or some other member shall rep.
resent him as the meeting may direct and
in all questions when the votes of the other
members shall be equal, the Chairman shall
have a casting vote.


| ART. 4. The Secretary shall keep fair
minutes ot the Soclcty's proceedings; coun-
tersign all orders on the Treasurer, and no.
tify members OF the time and place OF meet


ug,


ARTS. The Treasurer shall hold the
funds of the Association, and pay all orders
for money in his hands, drawn on him by
direction Of the Society, signed by the Pres
ident or one OF the vice Presidents, and coun-
tersigned by the Secretary.


ART. 6. The Acting Committee shall
CORES spond with individuals or societies in
our own or foreign countries, who may be
able to furnish information calculated to pro-
mote the objects OF this society, and shall
have particularly in view the encouragement
Of Free Labor in the slave districts Of the


United States, by promoting the consump.
tion of its products as widely AS practicable


and by such other means as may appear tc


be adapted to tha, important end


ART. 7. The meetings Of this socict,
shall be held quarterly, on the second Mon
day in January, April, July and October


and at any intermediate tunes, either by ad


ournment, Of by call of the President ant
Secretary, CT any five members Of the asso


cat on.


ART, 8. Any person may become mcm


Der Of this Society by signing the constitu


ton and paying to the Treasurer the sum 0
, fifty cents


A ART. Q, Six members shall constitute
, quorum for the transaction OF business. AM
: all questions, except such as relate to alter
S atcns OF the constitution, shall be decide
: by the majority of members present.
= ART. 10. All monies except the admis


sion fees, necessary for the use Of the socie


ty, shall be raised among the members b
: voluntary contribution.


e ART. IL. The members Of this associatio
: shall give preference to particles the produc
. of Free Labor, where such can be procure
:, without pecuniary sacrifice.
ART. 10. No alterations shall DC mad
= in this constitution, except the propositiu
" to alter shall have been made at precedir
- meeting, and shall be agreed to by thre,
oi fourths of the members present.

full articles.headline: FROM COLOMBIA,
full articles.article:
The adviccs from Carthagcna, TO the 10th hlt.
by the Bunker Hill. states, says the New-York
Mercantile, that Bolivar arrived at Bogota on the
18th of November, and proceeded for Venczue-
la OIL the 25th, From thence he was expected
TO arrive at Carthagena about the 10th to the 15th
Of January. The seat of Government was to be
established for the present at the latter place, or
at Turbaco, - miles distant. The private let
tiers, state, that on arriving at Bogota, Bolivar
took decisive measures to restore order--that he
invested himself with the authority given him by
the Constitution in cases of insnrrecton; that he
had despatched Santander to Peru, abolished
the officers of Secretary of Foreign Affairs and
of the Navy--ordercd the ARMY to be reduced 70
5000 men, and increased the pay of the officers
in tine navy 100 per cent. The intcntlant at Car
thagena, was to be removed. 1t is also stated
that a Convention of the people was to be called.
The letters enclose the following Proclamation


PROCLAMATION OF BOLIVAR.


Colombians Five years since left this capito
to march at the head of the Liberating army tron
the shore of the Cauca to the silvery heights Of
Potosi. million of Colombians, two sister Re
publcs, have obtained independence under the

sether With threats of rctaiiaton ut the ILL
human treatment it was supposed the gener-
al had received from the encmy, viz that
he had been bayonctted after having surrcn-
dered and asked for quarters: when the
magnanimous Mercer observcd--Ihe tale
which you have heard, George, is untrue
My death is owing to myself. was on foot,
endeavoring to rally my men, who had gwen
way before the superior discipline OF the en-
emy. when was brought to the ground by
blow from a musket. At the same moment
the enemy discovered my rank, exulted in
their having taken he rebel general, as
they termed me, and bid me ask Tor quar-
ters. | felt that deserved not so opprobrl-
Gus an epithet, and determined to die as had
lived, an honored soldier in a just and right
eous cause; and without begging my lite or
making reply, lunged with my sword at
the nearest man. They then bayonetted and
left me.


While the surgeons were dressing his
wounds. of which he had received thirteen,
the general, who was himself regularly
bred and eminent surgeon, remanded, "Nef-
cr mind those; they are mere scratches
Look under my arm, and there you viii Ind
fellow that will soon do my business"


We shall here rcpubish an anecdote
(Which we have given in another work. ct
the noble and dsinterested devotion OF the
amentcd Mercer, to that "just and righteous
cause" which he sealed with his blood on
the field Of Princeton.


When the southern troops we're first or
ganizing for the Army Of independence, nu-
merous applications for commissions were
made 10 the House OF Burgcsses of Virginia.
They were mostly from young men of for
tune and family interest, and seldom asked
for less than field officers rank. Mercer,
a veteran associate OF Washington in the
war of SO, and deservedly high in his conf
dcncc aud esteem, pressed not in the crowd,
urged no solicitations, sought no patronage,
but wrote on scrap OF paper and handed 1t
to the speaker, with the following words
"IIugh Mercer will serve his country in any
rank to which he may be appointed" He
received regiment forthwith.


He lies buried in Philadelphia, where a
plain slab, with the initials II NJ. denotes
the last earthly dwelling Of the patriot
brave.

full articles.headline:
From Curtis's Recollections cf Uashiagton
DEATH OF GENERAL MERCER,
full articles.article:
Our work will contain memoirs of many
of the distinguished worthless, who shared
with their chief the perils and glorles of the
tays of trial. Their virtues and heroic ac-
tions can no where be better commemorated
than in eRecollections" of him who was at
once their revered commander, father, and
friend.


The historical registers of the war of the
revolution are all in error, in their narratives
of the death of Gen. Mercer. We offer the
homage of our veneration for his martyred
memory, in giving to his country and the
world authentic details of the heroism and
devotion, which attended his fall.-Our au-
thority is derived from the late Major Geo.
Lewis, the nephew, of the commander-in-
chief. captain Of his guard, and who was sent
in with Gag to afford to the wounded gen
eral every possible comfort and assistance,
and in whose arms the lamented hero ex-
pired.


Lewis expressed the extreme indignation
which prevailed in the American army, to-

The Sierra Leone Gazette of the 9th s,p,sn.
lions most atrocious act Of barbarity, on the part
Of a French slave Captain, named Gibson This
fellow had carried off from the Gallinas, about
six weeks before, 250 slaves, whom he INTENDED
to introduce surreptitiously into Guadaloupe
He succeeded in landing the whole, except 6i,
when having observed French Government
cutter coming towards his vessel, he threw sixty.
five miserable beings overheard, in order to AVOID
discovery of the traffic he had been carving
on! The Governor of Gaudaloupe, it is added
gave orders to seize the murderer, when the crime
he had perpetrated was discovered by the deai
bodies that were drfted ashore, but he had soil
ed before the order could be executed.

and robbed at benicastle, on the road dFlNa sl

ductor of the other received twen,, .uN =.

the travellers all pillaged. S''

able aspect = N''


"The news from Greece is. in every ;.

the Turkish feet was at Mytene; that A.
the Greeks at Samos, which place The f,'

They may now be considered in stat. ~
inactivity quite hors de 6ataiYc In r.i.s

ings, had arrived at Napoli di Romaui, :
Upon the whole, fortune at present smiles
upon us; and, should she still be propitiou,
in our behalf, this year will, in all proba


bility. restore liberty and independenc. /,
I Greece"

A singular piece of cunning was practssa
upon the Magistrates of this Borough, a.
their sitting on Thursday last An informa
tion had been laid. the previous week, a.
gainst young man ofthe Society of Friend,
tor letting off fireworks, and summon,
was issued for the attendance Of the suppo,.
ed culprlt, who had been convicted Of sim.
liar offence on former occasion; but when
the constable was called upon to swear 10th.
person of this offender. 10 behold three QUO.
kers in outward appearance, dressed so pre-.
cisely alike as to set his recollection a. def
ance, stood before him, and as he was una
BILE to point out the real person conviction
was impossible. At the same sitting Char.;
Peck was convicted in the penalty often shi!.
lings for similar offence.-Bury Post

full articles.headline:
CONGRESS.-2d SESSION.


(coMPILBp FROM THE NATIONAL JOURNAL.
full articles.article:
In the Senate on Tuesday, 9th inst. the "Bil
TO provide for the location Of the two townships
of land reserved for seminary of learning in the
Territory of Florida, and to complete the loca-
ton Of the grant to the Deaf and Dumb Asylum
of Kentucky" after some discussion, was order
ed to a third reading. The "Bill to graduate the
price Of public land, and to cedc the refuse to
the States in which they lie," was considered,
and strongly opposed, in an able speech, by Mr..
Barton The bill, with an amendment, propos-
ed by Mr.. Hendricks, was postponed TO the Goth
inst.


In the House Of Representatives the day
was entirely occupied in the discussion of the
resolutions laid on the table the preceding day,
by Mr.. Blair, Of Tennessee, and Mr. Wiclifie Of
Kentucky. The two former were agreed to,
with amendments; and the discussion OF the lat.
ter was suspended by call for the orders of the
day. The further consideration of the Resolu-
tionary Officers and Soldiers bill was postponed
until tomorrow.


The select committe appointed on the subject
of the letter Of the Vice President on motion of
Mr.. Floyd, obtained leave to sit during the sit
ting ofthe House.


The system Of Cavalry Tractics prepared by
the Board of Officers which of Gen Scott was
President, was received from the War Depart
ment, and ordered 10 be printed.


In the Senate. the bill authorizing the Presid
ent ofthe United States to cause the reserved
lead mines of Missouri to be exposed to sale. was
considered, and after some discussion, was laid
on the table. The bill for opening military roads
in the Territory of Michigan. was then taken up,
and after an animated debate, was laid on the
table.


In the House Of Representatives, Mr.. Mercer
laid resolution on the table calling for nforma-
ton relative to the Custom House receipts from
1885, TO the present time. A Bill was reported
from the Committee on Manufactures, relative to
duties on imports; and bill from the Military
Committee, to increase the Corps OF Engineers.
The resolution offered by Mr.. wicklhee, and
discussed on the preceding day, was adopted
with modification The House then went into
Committee on the bill providing for the rclin.
9uishment of certain claims to lands sold by the
United States in the State of Ohio, but rose with
aut taking vote upon it, and obtained leave tc
sit again. message from the President Wa
received, communicating an interesting repor
from the Secretary of the Navy, relative TO ID!
Docks; and communication from the War De
partment, containing the names OF the officers o
the Revolutionary Army, as far as they could b'
furnished.


In the Senate, on Thursday, bill was report
cd for reducing the duties on certain importc'
articles. A bill was reported for increasing tn
sa...rv Of the Post Master General to G,O0O do
lars. Mr. nickerson, from the Select Commit
tee TO which was referred the bill for distributing
a portion of the national revenue among III
States, reported the same Mr. Smith, OF Nd
submitted aresolution proposing an inquiry int
the expedency ofreducing the balance ofthe tw
millions authorized TO be kept in the Treasury
20 one million, and Of appropria;ing the same t
the payment OF the debt due to the Coinmlssior
era Of the Sinking Fund,


The House of Representatives was principal
occupied in the discussion OF the Reyolltlonar
Bill, but adjourned without coming to vote
slr Livingston moved the House to take up h
resolution on the subject of the Greeks, and ash
ed for the ayes and noes on the question, who
ehe House refused TO consiusr it, by vote
100 to 54


In the Senate on Friday, the bill to reduce ii
duties on imported wines, teas, gunpowder, ar
salt, was read second time. The bill to increa'
the salary of the Post Master General was aft'
come discussion, ordered to third reading. TT
bill to establish an uniform system OF Bankruptc
throughout the United States, was made the sp
cial order of the day for Monday next.


The House of Representatives was engaged
the discussion of the bill to provide for the of
GERS and soldiers of the army Of the Revolutio
The question was taken by Ayes and Noes,
motion Of Mr.. Tucker, which was negatived by
vote of 160to 80 Mr. WickhHe then moved
Introduce the words "and the heirs and repr
sentatves ofthose who have dicd,' and on Il
question the ayes and noes were ordered, hut b
fore the question was taken, the House adjour
ed.


The Senate did not sit on Saturday.


In the House of Representatives, the di
cussion OF the Bill to make provision for Il
officers and soldiers OF the army of the Re
olution was resumed; but no question W
taken. Mr.. Wickliffe made few observ
ba md fnI
BY Mr.. Test and Mr.. Clarke against t
bill, and Mr.. Sprague and Mr., Drayton,


the other side. Mr.. Wecms also obtain
the floor, and then yielded it to motion


adjournment.

and affection displayed towards them and
the soldiers.


The Bank of England has declared half
yearly dividend Of A. per cent.


Gen. Outrage, who with many others OF
the Constitutional Exllcs remains in London
has declared his intention OF Immediately
leaving that country, and proceeding to Por-
Sugal, to range himself under the banners,
and to fight the battles of the Constitution.
II is said that several hundreds ofthc Span
ish and Italian refugees have also resolved
to accompany him.


Letters from Madrid state, that the Por-
tuguese insurgents were supplied with arms
from the Spanish factories, and that orders
have been given to the Supreme Council of
War to report as to the most prompt and et-
fectual manner of raising 0,o00 men.


The Courier Francois says, that the lead
ers of the Portuguese refugees have receiv.
ed from Paris the advice to seize as they ad
vance in Portugal, all property belonging to
British merchants, not only to indemnify
themselves for the expenses of the expedi-
ton but e. create forthenselves guarantee e
in case of ultrrior events. Whether advised
or not, it seems they adopted this course
when they pundcred Braganza.


The forces under the insurgent Chiei, the
Marquis Chaves, amounted to 5000, when
he entered Portugal. and it was supposed
they would soon swell to 5000.


PORTUGAL.-The following is an ex-
tract of private letter from Oporto.


"OPORTO, Dec. l, 1926.


.'NVe were all in great CONSERVATION this
morning on account of the news from the
frontiers. The Marquis de Chaves has en-
tered Braganza with 2090 men, and there
beng only 500 regular troops in the place
they fought and retired to the castle. AT
terwards general sack took place; every
house was robbed, aud the female inhabit
ants insulted; the carnage was great among
the troops. What is most to be dreaded il
the rise ofsthe sans culotte, to whom il
promised a pilIage, and they are ripe fol
it,"


The Portuguese Government, whicl
learned on the morning of the 23d, the inva
Sion OF lras-os- Montes, wrote by the Min
lister of Foreign Affairs the same evening Il
the Marquis dc Casa Flores. the Spanish
Ambassador at Lisbon, that his functions a
Ambassador were at an end, and that when
ever he wished, passports to quit Portuga
would be given to him. This fact is exact
very exact---and there is no doubt that TIL
Portuguese Government would not have a
adopted this abrupt proceeding withou
the advice of Sir w. A'Court, it is pre-
sumed that its conduct will regulate that q
Mr.. Lamb, who will doubtless terminate hi
mission at Madrid in as abrupt way as tina
Of NJ dc Casa Flores ended at Lisbon.


The struggle which took place at bragan
' "a appears To have been a very seyrrr one
for we are assured the number killed AN
wounded OH Tie two sides amounted to abou
500 men.

full articles.headline:
N.MPON'EAEY NEW 5.

WAR BBTWEEN SPAIN, PORTUGAL AND


ENGLAND.
full articles.article:
brings london papers to the l4th ult. which
furnish the important intelligence, that For
tugal, having been invaded by spain, had
called upon the British Government, in con-
formitv with it's treaty of alliance, for aid,
and that the latter, without delay, answer
cd the call.


Upon this measure of the British Gov
ernnent, the New York American remarks:
at is not 10 be disguised that this step in
Europe, is of the greatest moment to us. ana
every eye in this country will at once be
turned towards Cuba. the only possession OF
spain that can alone compensate Great Brit
ain for the expenses and evils of a war with
that power--a jewel alike rich and unde'
Tended: Mr. Canning takes, it will be oo-
| served, the distinction, and insists upon u
, hat this is war, MT against SPAN, Dut III
defence of Portugal-not OF aggression, but
of reprcsslon;--and j. that ground be ad-
hcred to, it would exclude the idea OF con
quest But the temptation is great--the
facilities great. the prize invaluable On
the other hand, France and the tniteI States
/ will not, cannot. acquiesce in the island OF
Cuba passing under British dominion; and
an attempt therefore TO wrest that island
from Span, unless under the most positive
and SUBSTANTIAL pledges that its mdepen-
dcncc. under the guaranty of all the three
nations, shall be- the consequence. win lead
most certainly To universal war. II is prop
er, however, to say. that, according TO the
! London papers az different politics, it wa,
not anticipated that the war would involve
other powers, or be Of long duration"


The Parliament adjourned OIL the 3th of


December to the 9Th Of February. Mr.. Peal
gave notice that the subject of the Corn
Laws will be brought before the house Of


Parliament on the twelfth Of February,


when the views of Ministers will be fully
explained.


On the 18th Of December the King Of Eng


land transmitted the following message to


Pariament


"0eorgs Il.


His Majesty acuiain.s the House of Com-


mons, that his Majesty has received an ear


nest application from the Princess Regent of


Portugal, claiming, in virtue Of the ancient


obligations of alliance and amty subsisting


between his Majesty and the crown of POI.


tugal, his Majesty aid against an hostile
aggression from Spain.


"His Majesty has excrted himself for


some time past. in conjunction with his Ma
icsty's ally, the king Of France, TO prevent
such an aggl ession; and repeated assuran-
ces have bttp given by the court OF Madrid
of the determination Of his Catholic Majesty


neither to commit, nor allow to be commit
, ted, from his Catholic Majcsty's territory,
an aggression against Portugal.


"But his majesty has learned with deep
concern, that notwithstanding these assuran-


ces, hostile nroads into the territory Of Po--
= tugal have concerted in Spain. and have been
executed in the eyes Of Spanish authorities


BY Portuguese regiments which had desert
cd into Spain, and which the Spanish Gov
crumcnt had repeatedly and solemnly en-
= gagged to dsarm and to disptrse.


/, "I1is Majesty leaves no effort unexhaust-
u cd to awaken the Spanish Government to


the dangerous consequence OF this apparent


connivaucc.


ellis Majesty makes this communication
to the House Of Commons with the full and
u entire confidence that his Majesty's faithful


Commons will afford his Majesty their COR
= dial concurrence and support in maintaining
u the faith OF treaties, and in securing agains,
foreign hostility tho safety and independence
q Of Portugal, tho oldest Ally Of Great Brit


ain"


On the 18th, when ON the subject Of tn,
8 Message, Mr.. Canning explained the rcla
y tions that existed with Portugal, and wen


on to state, "On the Sd Of September tn,
;" first application was made to our Govern
y, ment by the Portuguese ambassador for as
W sistance. On Friday evening Government
was satisfied Of all the facts necessary t.
: make case necessary tor our interference
'i and on Saturday came to a decision upo
u these facts. On Monday the Message wa
G sent to Parliament, and at the moment


am speaking, troops are on the way to Por


tuga.


The British troops we're moving with a
It. much promptness as the ministry have actet
TX The second battalion of the third regimen
he of Guards left London ON the 18th to embar
le, at Portsmouth. "There were at the tim
eu g, many thousand persons assembled who rel
~, IN the air with shouts of "Success Guards."-
" " "Success, my boys" -"Portugal forever,
W The men seemed to be in excellent spirit
,,r and to be much pleased with the nature
he the service on which they were to cmbarl
bv it seems that those who remain behind, wit
he few exceptions; express deep regret at n,
,ed having been selected. The troops chose
md are chiefly veterans. At ten o'clock. CT
70 Bowater, who has the command of the ba
ers talon, gave the word to march, and the so
ar diers quilted the park, amid the acclaim
ted tions of the numerous spectators. The d

BILE in consequence OF the crowd, who pr

4iUIiEd, NV -


"The Marquis de Bolgida, Comptroller
General had a sudden attack of apoplexy,
which ended. as it MAS thought, ia his death,
He was dressed in the habit Of Monk. as is
the common custom of our country, and de-
posted III the vault of the Church Of St,
Iuste, his parish


"However, at eleven o'clock. last night,
the Marquis awoke from his lcthargy, rails
ed himself from the coffin (for in general our
collins are not fastcned) and his fear giving
him additional strength, he made lis way to
the grating Of the vault opening to the street,
and called to the FIRST person he saw, who,
frightened IN hrs turn, ran away AS fast as
he could, calling out that ghosts were Com
ing forth from the vault of St, Juste. The
Marquis finding himself thus treated, recol-
lected the name of IA carpenter known to
him, and who lived opposite, and called on
him SO loudly, that he succeeded in waking
him. The carpenter went out, and though
not much pleased to hear himself called up
OH from place, the inhabitants of which
are generally very taciturn, by degrees, col
lected his thoughts, understood what the
Marquis wished him to do and went mme-
diately to give the Cure Of the Parish an ac-
count of what had taken place. The Mar
quis was liberated from the vault and taken
to his home, where lie now remains i'll in bed
and on the point Of really dying, through the
supposed death which he lately suffered.

Cast Metal Pianos.-Every day the use
Of cast iron is becoming more general
bridges are made OF it; steam boats; in Eng
land it is used for roads; and az Liverpool
churches are built of it. Here. in Paris, we
have lately got Pianos, the frame work OF
which is formed Of cast iron, These nstru-
ments have been brought to such perfection
by MN. pleyel and Co, that not only do
they rival, but 10 many particulars, surpass
the best English Instruments. The soldity

Paris, Nov. e0--On Friday night, at IL
o'clock, an individual, who was passing IN
the Rue DIES Fosscs. .MOntmartre, where he
lodged, was accostcd BY four robbers, who
demanded his purse. Upon his offering re-
sistance, thrY wrapped towel about his
head, stabbed him i'll seven places in the left
arm, threw him down, and took from him
watch, and about four thousand francs,
which were enclosed in belt. 1t seems
that two persons, passing "A moment after
wards, when he was still mpluring assist
ance fed from him, supposing his cries were
but the manGuvre OF some assassin These
persons, meeting a party of gen-d' 'armes,
sent them to the spot, where they picked up
the man and conve, ed him to the Commls-
sarv of Police, to whom he related what had
happened. He remained there fnr the night
| and patroles were sent out in all directions.
| The wounds, we understand, are likely to
be OF serious consequence. The Williams un-
fortunately escaped. Upon Change it was
said yesterday, that the man inflicted the
wounds upon himself, and pretended he had
been robbed, in order to account for the alb
sense Of considerable sum which he had


lost by gambling. The horses of u gentle
mans carriage, which was waiting near one
of the theatres, i'll the absence Of the coach
man, were Embarrassed and taken away,
and no trace as yet been found OF them. 1t
is dangerous to walk the streets at night


You will scarcely credit i, but person was


stopped and robbed OF his watch last week
on the pont des Arts, where there is a toll


keeper and guards at each cnd.--Distress
; however, seems to be the grand cause ot


these crimes. for of the numbers who have


hcen arrested, the greater part are III the
most dreadful state.
